citations.narrative:
The licensee does not have an adequate written contingency plan. The contingency plan did not address requirements
including plans for all reasonably anticipated disasters or emergency scenarios, nor does it describe how the housing and
care of the animals would be accomplished. An inadequate contingency plan can result in lack of readiness and a delay in
response to care for animals during emergencies or disasters. Dealers must develop, document, and follow an
appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the
event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good
health and well-being of the animals in their possession). A contingency plan includes emergency situations the licensee
may experience, outlines specific tasks required to be carried out during emergencies such as detailed animal evacuation
instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food and water as well as
sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, identify who will be responsible for fulfilling these tasks, and address how
response and recovery will be handled in terms of materials, resources, and training needed. Ensure that an adequate
written contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency. Correct by 30-JULY-2023.

A primary enclosure contains carpet that is in disrepair with frayed edges. An enclosure housing an adult female dog with
a litter has soiled carpet that is torn and damaged. Frayed edges can be injurious to the regulated animal as they could
ingest the material or could cause entrapment. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing
facilities—including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility—that cannot be readily
cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. The carpets must be maintained without frayed edges.

Enclosures are not being cleaned properly. In two outdoor enclosures housing 6 dogs each the walls of the inside of the
sheltered structures are soiled with a buildup of brown material and in a third outdoor enclosure housing 3 dogs the walls
of the sheltered structure are soiled with green and brown material. The buildup of material covers a significant portion of
the sheltered structures. Inadequate and infrequent cleaning and sanitization allows for the growth of disease-causing
agents that may increase the risk of health hazards towards the animals. Appropriate cleaning and sanitization of the
surfaces must include removal of the buildup of brown and green material found and to prevent accumulation of this
material. All surfaces of housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted
husbandry standards and practices. Correct by ensuring hard surfaces with which the dogs come into contact with are
spot cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with 3.11 (B) of this sub part to prevent accumulation of excreta and
reduce disease hazards.

The licensee does not maintain complete medical records for adult dogs. The licensee states that aside from the recent
Rabies vaccinations given to the adult dogs, they do not have records of any other vaccines and treatments they state
they have administered or the dates of administration. Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere with the
ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Complete medical records
must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration.
Correct by documenting all treatments given and ensure that medical records are complete and contain the required
information. Correct by 3-JULY-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The licensee does not have an adequate written contingency plan. The contingency plan did not address requirements 
including plans for all reasonably anticipated disasters or emergency scenarios, nor does it describe how the housing and 
care of the animals would be accomplished. An inadequate contingency plan can result in lack of readiness and a delay in 
response to care for animals during emergencies or disasters. Dealers must develop, document, and follow an 
appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the 
event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good 
health and well-being of the animals in their possession). A contingency plan includes emergency situations the licensee 
may experience, outlines specific tasks required to be carried out during emergencies such as detailed animal evacuation 
instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food and water as well as 
sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, identify who will be responsible for fulfilling these tasks, and address how 
response and recovery will be handled in terms of materials, resources, and training needed. Ensure that an adequate 
written contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency. Correct by 30-JULY-2023. 
3.1(c)(2)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A primary enclosure contains carpet that is in disrepair with frayed edges. An enclosure housing an adult female dog with 
a litter has soiled carpet that is torn and damaged. Frayed edges can be injurious to the regulated animal as they could 
ingest the material or could cause entrapment. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing 
facilities—including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility—that cannot be readily 
cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. The carpets must be maintained without frayed edges. 
3.1(c)(3)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Enclosures are not being cleaned properly. In two outdoor enclosures housing 6 dogs each the walls of the inside of the 
sheltered structures are soiled with a buildup of brown material and in a third outdoor enclosure housing 3 dogs the walls 
of the sheltered structure are soiled with green and brown material. The buildup of material covers a significant portion of 
the sheltered structures. Inadequate and infrequent cleaning and sanitization allows for the growth of disease-causing 
agents that may increase the risk of health hazards towards the animals. Appropriate cleaning and sanitization of the

surfaces must include removal of the buildup of brown and green material found and to prevent accumulation of this 
material. All surfaces of housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted 
husbandry standards and practices. Correct by ensuring hard surfaces with which the dogs come into contact with are 
spot cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with 3.11 (B) of this sub part to prevent accumulation of excreta and 
reduce disease hazards. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee does not maintain complete medical records for adult dogs. The licensee states that aside from the recent 
Rabies vaccinations given to the adult dogs, they do not have records of any other vaccines and treatments they state 
they have administered or the dates of administration. Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere with the 
ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Complete medical records 
must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration. 
Correct by documenting all treatments given and ensure that medical records are complete and contain the required 
information. Correct by 3-JULY-2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
